revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2019}} {{Infobox song | name = DNA | cover = Little Mix - DNA (Official Single Cover).png | alt = A greyscale image of Little Mix laying next to each other centered around the title "DNA" in red. | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Little Mix]] | album = [[DNA (Little Mix album)|DNA]] | released = {{Start date|2012|11|9|df=yes}} | format = *[[CD single]] *[[Music download|digital download]] | genre = *[[Electropop]] *[[Synth-pop|techno-pop]] | length = {{duration|m=03|s=56}} | label = [[Syco Music|Syco]] | writer = {{hlist|Thomas Barnes|Peter Kelleher|Ben Kohn|[[Iain James]]|[[Perrie Edwards]]|[[Jesy Nelson]]|[[Leigh-Anne Pinnock]]|[[Jade Thirlwall]]}} | producer = [[TMS (production team)|TMS]] | prev_title = [[Wings (Little Mix song)|Wings]] | prev_year = 2012 | next_title = [[Change Your Life (Little Mix song)|Change Your LIfe]] | next_year = 2013 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|D3h-lLj3xv4|"DNA"}}}} }}
"'''DNA'''" is a song by British [[girl group]] [[Little Mix]] from their 2012 [[DNA (Little Mix album)|debut studio album of the same name]]. The song was written by the group members, production team [[TMS (production team)|TMS]] and songwriter [[Iain James]], and was inspired by the band's performance of [[Katy Perry]]'s 2010 single "[[E.T. (song)|E.T.]]" as contestants on [[The X Factor (UK series 8)|the eighth UK series]] of the British television talent show ''[[The X Factor (UK TV series)|The X Factor]]''. "DNA" is a mid-tempo [[electropop]] and [[Synth-pop|techno-pop]] track featuring eerie [[Synthesizer|synths]], a [[music box]] introduction, spoken-word [[middle eight]] and elements of [[dubstep]]. The lyrics stem from the group members' experiences with love, and have a theme of obsession.
Released as the album's second single on 9 November 2012, "DNA" debuted at number three on the [[UK Singles Chart]], making it the band's third successive single to chart in the top three. It also reached the top 10 in Ireland and Hungary, and charted at number 14 on the US [[Bubbling Under Hot 100]]. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics, who complimented its synth production and choral interlude.
The track's music video was directed by [[Sarah Chatfield]] and portrays the group as assassins who stalk and kidnap a man, inspired by the comic books ''[[Sin City]]'' and ''[[Watchmen]]''. Little Mix promoted "DNA" with televised performances on ''[[Loose Women]]'', ''[[T4 (Channel 4)|T4]]'', and [[The X Factor (UK series 9)|the ninth UK series]] of ''The X Factor''. The song was performed as part of four of the group's concert tours, including [[The Glory Days Tour]] in 2017.
==Background== Little Mix co-wrote "DNA" with production team [[TMS (production team)|TMS]], and songwriter [[Iain James]].<ref name="Notes"/> The song was inspired by the group members' personal experiences with love; Perrie Edwards said the group "perform better when the lyrics mean something to [them] when [they] sing them."<ref name="Seventeen">{{cite web|url=https://www.seventeen.com/celebrity/g331/little-mix/|title=17 Minutes With Little Mix|last=Laurence|first=Emily|website=[[Seventeen (American magazine)|Seventeen]]|date=14 January 2013|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306042838/https://www.seventeen.com/celebrity/g331/little-mix/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The song was intended as a darker and more mature contrast to the group's previous single "[[Wings (Little Mix song)|Wings]]", in a style akin to their 2011 performance of [[Katy Perry]]'s "[[E.T. (song)|E.T.]]" on the [[The X Factor (UK series 8)|eighth UK series]] of the British television talent show ''[[The X Factor (UK TV series)|The X Factor]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/blackberry/p.html?id=2191107|title=Little Mix Talk 'DNA', Gaining Respect And Why 'Being A Girl Is Hard' (Interview)|last=Dean|first=Sarah|website=[[HuffPost]]|date=26 November 2012|accessdate=5 May 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GQdzqKCQ?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/blackberry/p.html?id=2191107|archivedate=7 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> Jesy Nelson said, "'Wings' was very upbeat and fun and colourful, and we wanted to show how versatile we were".<ref name="Jesy">{{cite web|url=https://www.popjustice.com/articles/an-interview-with-jesy-from-little-mix/104446/|title=An interview with Jesy from Little Mix|last=O'Mance|first=Brad|website=[[Popjustice]]|date=23 November 2012|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306042921/https://www.popjustice.com/articles/an-interview-with-jesy-from-little-mix/104446/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> According to Jade Thirlwall, the group "just wanted to write about a boy, but without making it typical. We came up with the scientific idea and then started matching science words with love."<ref name="The Guardian Interview">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/nov/22/little-mix-look-like-dirty-mingers|title=Little Mix: 'We all look like dirty mingers underneath!'|last=Jonze|first=Tim|author-link=Tim Jonze|website=[[The Guardian]]|date=22 November 2012|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020150707/http://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/nov/22/little-mix-look-like-dirty-mingers|archive-date=20 October 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> It was one of two songs being considered for release as the album's second single; the group chose "DNA" believing it better showcased their vocals and a more serious side to their personalities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.glamourmagazine.co.uk/article/little-mix-wings-interview-debut-album|title=Little Mix Wings Interview|last=Selby|first=Jenn|website=[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]|date=31 August 2012|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409151620/http://www.glamourmagazine.co.uk/article/little-mix-wings-interview-debut-album|archive-date=9 April 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
==Composition== {{listen | pos = right | filename = Little Mix - DNA.ogg | title = "DNA" | description = A 24 second sample of "DNA", featuring the song's choral interlude and the group harmonising the [[refrain]] "It's in his DNA, d-d-d-DNA". | format = [[Ogg]] }} "DNA" is composed in the [[Key (music)|key]] of [[E-flat minor|E{{music|flat}} minor]] using [[Time signature|{{music|time|4|4}} time]] and a tempo of 70 beats per minute. Little Mix's vocal range spans from E{{music|flat}}<sub>3</sub> to C{{music|flat}}<sub>5</sub>. The verses follow a [[chord progression]] of E{{music|flat}}m–C{{music|flat}}–G{{music|flat}}–B{{music|flat}}m/F.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0111836|title=Little Mix "DNA" Sheet Music in Eb Minor|website=Musicnotes.com|accessdate=6 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306045009/https://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0111836|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> It is a midtempo,<ref name="Popjustice">{{cite web|url=https://www.popjustice.com/briefing/dna-wails-of-princesses/|title='DNA' – wails of princesses|website=Popjustice|date=28 September 2012|accessdate=6 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306043728/https://www.popjustice.com/briefing/dna-wails-of-princesses/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> [[electropop]] and [[Synth-pop|techno-pop]] song,<ref name="Sunday Mail">{{cite newspaper|title=7 Tunes; This Week's Essential Download Tracks|newspaper=[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]|location=Glasgow|date=11 November 2012|page=7}}</ref><ref name="The Scotsman">{{cite web|url=https://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/music/cd-reviews-little-mix-olly-murs-1-2659203|title=CD Reviews: Little Mix|last=Shepherd|first=Fiona|website=[[The Scotsman]]|date=26 November 2012|accessdate=5 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106132325/https://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/music/cd-reviews-little-mix-olly-murs-1-2659203|archive-date=6 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> with a pronounced, grinding beat<ref name="Alim Kheraj">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/feature/a791598/little-mix-singles-ranked-which-hit-is-our-no1/|title=Little Mix's 14 hit singles ranked: Which is our No.1?|last=Kheraj|first=Alim|website=Digital Spy|date=27 November 2016|accessdate=6 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807014155/http://www.digitalspy.com/music/feature/a791598/little-mix-singles-ranked-which-hit-is-our-no1/|archive-date=7 August 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> and elements of [[dubstep]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesinglesjukebox.com/?p=6200|title=Little Mix – DNA|website=The Singles Jukebox|date=17 October 2012|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306044036/http://www.thesinglesjukebox.com/?p=6200|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The track is led by spooky synthesizers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://renownedforsound.com/index.php/little-mix-dna/|title=Album Review: Little Mix – DNA|last=Veevers|first=Brendon|website=[[Renowned for Sound]]|date=15 November 2012|accessdate=6 November 2018}}{{Dead link|date=July 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="10tracks"/> and features drums and guitar.<ref name="Notes"/> The first verse is introduced by a tinkling [[music box]] and pumping [[heart rate monitor]], and is performed by Edwards in a low [[vocal register]].<ref name="Popjustice"/><ref name="10tracks">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/thesound/a409354/playlist-10-tracks-you-need-to-hear.html|title=Playlist: 10 tracks you need to hear|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=1 October 2012|accessdate=16 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gdi1PdWJ?url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/thesound/a409354/playlist-10-tracks-you-need-to-hear.html|archivedate=15 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> After a pre-chorus by Thirlwall, all four group members harmonise the pounding refrain,<ref name="Alim Kheraj"/><ref name="Shields Gazette">{{cite web|url=https://www.shieldsgazette.com/whats-on/music/album-review-little-mix-s-dna-track-by-track-1-5138028|title=Album review: Little Mix's DNA, track-by-track|last=Newman|first=Vicki|website=[[Shields Gazette]]|date=16 November 2012|accessdate=6 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190218021326/https://www.shieldsgazette.com/whats-on/music/album-review-little-mix-s-dna-track-by-track-1-5138028|archive-date=18 February 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref> which is backed by slamming and smashing noises. After Nelson's second verse, Thirlwall's second pre-chorus and the second chorus, the song nearly stops.<ref name="Popjustice"/> It then enters into a spoken-word [[middle eight]] performed by Leigh-Anne Pinnock in a modulated, robotic style, which is followed by a choral interlude.<ref name="Alim Kheraj"/> The third and final chorus is preceded by brief [[Rave music|rave]] klaxons and a high note sung by Edwards.<ref name="Popjustice"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://attitude.co.uk/article/every-little-mix-single-ranked-in-order-of-greatness/12928/|title=Little Mix's singles ranked in order of greatness|last=Passmore|first=Joe|website=[[Attitude (magazine)|Attitude]]|date=31 October 2018|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306044403/https://attitude.co.uk/article/every-little-mix-single-ranked-in-order-of-greatness/12928/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
According to Pinnock, "DNA" is "not just a love song, it's about being obsessed with someone to the extreme. And sometimes when things go bad you do go like that, you stalk them on [[Facebook]] ..."<ref name="The Guardian Interview"/> Nelson said the group play a character in the song and portray themselves to be darker than they are.<ref name="Jesy"/> Edwards said that when stripped of its scientific words, "DNA" is just a love song<ref name="The Guardian Interview"/> about "when a girl first gets with a boy, that kind of romance makes you feel really giddy and happy".<ref name="Seventeen"/>
==Release== Details about "DNA" emerged after music industry insiders previewed it at a conference held by [[Sony Music Entertainment]] on 11 September 2012.<ref name="Details">{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a405535/little-mix-to-release-dna-as-new-single/|title=Little Mix to release 'DNA' as new single|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=[[Digital Spy]]|date=12 September 2012|accessdate=5 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306044040/https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a405535/little-mix-to-release-dna-as-new-single/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Little Mix shared the single's cover art on [[Twitter]] on 30 September 2012.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=LittleMix|number=252407450278432768|title=Mixers! We are soooooo excited to show you the single cover for #DNA!! XxLittle Mix xX|date=30 September 2012|accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref> On 1 October 2012, a lyric video was posted on [[Vevo]] and the song had its radio premiere on [[Nick Grimshaw]]'s ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/new-single-dna-lyric-video/|title=Little Mix Unveil New Single 'DNA' Lyric Video And Debut Album Tracklisting|website=[[Capital (radio network)|Capital]]|date=1 October 2012|accessdate=5 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306044015/https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/new-single-dna-lyric-video/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a408483/little-mix-to-debut-new-single-dna-next-week/|title=Little Mix to debut new single next week|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=26 September 2012|accessdate=5 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306043153/https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a408483/little-mix-to-debut-new-single-dna-next-week/|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> A digital [[extended play]] (EP) was made available to pre-order from the [[iTunes Store]] the same day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.little-mix.com/gb/news/2012-10-01/listen-to-dna|title=Listen to DNA!|website=Little-Mix.com|date=1 October 2012|accessdate=12 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121118083512/http://www.little-mix.com/gb/news/2012-10-01/listen-to-dna|archivedate=18 November 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> It was released in Ireland on 9 November 2012 and then in the UK two days later.<ref name="IRE release">{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/ie/album/dna-ep/id563824664|title=DNA - EP|website=[[iTunes Store]] (IE)|accessdate=15 May 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gd9ujSTC?url=https://itunes.apple.com/ie/album/dna-ep/id563824664 |archivedate=15 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="UK release">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/B009RETQPU/ref=dm_aw_dp_sp_bb_sfa|title=DNA by Little Mix|website=[[Amazon Music]]|accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref>
To promote the release, Little Mix held a [[YouTube]] competition in which fans shared dance routines for the song. Three entrants won tickets to the group's [[DNA Tour]], a copy of their book ''Ready to Fly'', a copy of the album and a dance tutorial in London with the group's choreographer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/main-topics/homepage/773224/little-mix-announce-fan-dance-competition|title=Little Mix announce fan dance competition|last=Lucey|first=Kate|website=[[sugarscape.com]]|date=8 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211092708/http://www.sugarscape.com/main-topics/homepage/773224/little-mix-announce-fan-dance-competition|archive-date=11 February 2013|access-date=18 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> A two-track [[CD single]] packaged with the album ''DNA'' was made available exclusively from music retail chain [[HMV]] on 19 November 2012.<ref name="CD">{{cite web|url=http://hmv.com/hmvweb/displayProductDetails.do?ctx=280;-1;-1;-1;-1&sku=97851|title=Little Mix: Dna: Bonus Cd|website=[[HMV]]|accessdate=5 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109064343/http://hmv.com/hmvweb/displayProductDetails.do?ctx=280;-1;-1;-1;-1&sku=97851|archive-date=9 November 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.little-mix.com/gb/news/2012-10-24/dna-album|title=DNA Album|website=Little-mix.com|date=24 October 2012|accessdate=5 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306044035/https://www.little-mix.com/gb/news/2012-10-24/dna-album|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> An unpluggeed version of "DNA" is included in the deluxe edition of the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/B00CJ1UW24/ref=dm_aw_dp_sp_bb_sfa|title=DNA: The Deluxe Edition by Little Mix|website=Amazon Music|accessdate=19 March 2019}}</ref>
==Critical reception== [[File:2013 - Little Mix DNA Tour date at York Barbican Centre Little Mix (8462773232).jpg|thumb|left|Little Mix performing the song during their 2013 [[DNA Tour]].|alt=Little Mix performing in black and white outfits on stage.]]
"DNA" received generally positive reviews from music critics upon release. Lewis Corner of ''[[Digital Spy]]'' wrote, "Spooky synths, pumping heartbeats and a gothic choir finale make this pop perfection".<ref name="10tracks"/> In his review for the same website, Robert Copsey gave the track four stars out of five and said, "the epic, operatic middle eight is a pop moment this time they can claim entirely as their own".<ref name="Robert Copsey">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/single-reviews/review/a436074/little-mix-dna-single-review/|title=Little Mix: 'DNA' - Single review|last=Copsey|first=Robert|website=Digital Spy|date=6 November 2012|accessdate=17 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180626102231/http://www.digitalspy.com/music/single-reviews/review/a436074/little-mix-dna-single-review/|archive-date=26 June 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> ''[[DIY (magazine)|DIY]]'' magazine's Laurence Green called it a "great pop tune by any mark" that "sounds quite a bit like a [[Girls Aloud]] song" and "a sign of just how embedded Girls Aloud have become in the fabric of contemporary British pop".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diymag.com/archive/untouchable-why-the-return-of-girls-aloud-is-so-exciting|title=Untouchable: Why The Return Of Girls Aloud Is So Exciting|last=Green|first=Laurence|website=[[DIY (magazine)|DIY]]|date=9 October 2012|accessdate=17 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180704123939/http://diymag.com/archive/untouchable-why-the-return-of-girls-aloud-is-so-exciting|archive-date=4 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
Mark Davison of ''No Ripcord'' rated the track eight out of ten, calling it "giddy, glitzy pop which would do Girls Aloud, or at least [[The Saturdays]], proud", adding; "You'll know exactly what 'DNA' sounds like before you hear it, and that's no bad thing".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.noripcord.com/features/singles-bar-12th-november-2012|title=The Singles Bar: 12th November 2012|last=Davison|first=Mark|website=No Ripcord|date=13 November 2012|accessdate=22 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306174912/https://www.noripcord.com/features/singles-bar-12th-november-2012|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> In a review of the album ''DNA'', [[AllMusic]]'s Matt Collar cited the song among the "truly catchy, infectious cuts",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/dna-mw0002285818|title=DNA - Little Mix|website=[[AllMusic]]|last=Collar|first=Matt|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=24 May 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gqm3d1tp?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dna-mw0002285818|archivedate=24 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> while Malcolm Jack of ''[[The Guardian]]'' named it the album's best track, saying it "finally tests cautiously U-certificate boundaries".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/03/little-mix-review|title=Little Mix – review|last=Jack|first=Malcolm|website=The Guardian|date=3 February 2013|accessdate=19 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208062222/http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/03/little-mix-review|archive-date=8 February 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Another reviewer from ''The Guardian'' described the song as a "sprightly synth banger".<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=G2: Film & Music: The F&M Playlist|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=26 October 2012|page=17}}</ref>
In a less enthusiastic review, ''[[NME]]''{{'}}s Eve Barlow said the track sounds exactly like "E.T." and from "[[Tulisa]]'s school of 'ballid'".<ref name="NME">{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/various-artists/13872|title=Little Mix - 'DNA'|last=Barlow|first=Eve|website=[[NME]]|date=9 November 2012|accessdate=16 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GdjHmwS3?url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/various-artists/13872|archivedate=15 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> John Murphy of ''[[musicOMH]]'' commented, "It's woeful. It sounds dated, dull and auto-tuned to death. The chorus sounds like [[t.A.T.u]], there's a completely pointless yet apparently now obligatory rap, and unlike 'Wings', which was instantly memorable, this isn't."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicomh.com:80/music/features/track-reviews-8-14-oct_1012.htm|title=Track Reviews: 8-14 October 2012|last=Murphy|first=John|website=[[musicOMH]]|date=8 October 2012|accessdate=22 October 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128160220/http://www.musicomh.com/music/features/track-reviews-8-14-oct_1012.htm|archivedate=28 January 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> Eoin Butler of ''[[The Irish Times]]'' gave the song two stars out of five writing, "'It's in his DNA, his DNA.' (Y'know, it's actually probably his haircut.)"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/music/album-reviews/shuffle-1.552844|title=Shuffle|last=Butler|first=Eoin|website=[[The Irish Times]]|date=16 November 2012|accessdate=17 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306174911/https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/music/album-reviews/shuffle-1.552844|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Stuart Heritage wrote in ''The Guardian'' that it is "not a good song by anyone's standards".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/nov/11/x-factor-live-sixth-results-show|title=The X Factor live blog: sixth results show|last=Heritage|first=Stuart|website=The Guardian|date=11 November 2012|accessdate=18 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420131510/http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/nov/11/x-factor-live-sixth-results-show|archive-date=20 April 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
''Digital Spy'' placed the track at number 19 in its 2012 year-end list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a446278/20-best-singles-of-2012-20-11/|title=20 best singles of 2012 (20 - 11)|last1=Copsey|first1=Robert|last2=Corner|first2=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=20 November 2012|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180725113706/http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a446278/20-best-singles-of-2012-20-11/|archive-date=25 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> Michael Cragg and Kieran Yates included it in their 2012 year-end top-ten lists for ''The Guardian''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2012/dec/17/guardian-best-albums-2012-critics-individual-lists|title=The best albums of 2012: our critics' individual choices|website=The Guardian|date=17 December 2012|accessdate=19 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819151439/https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2012/dec/17/guardian-best-albums-2012-critics-individual-lists|archive-date=19 August 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2013, "DNA" was shortlisted for the [[Popjustice £20 Music Prize]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.popjustice.com/twentyquidmusicprize/|title=The Popjustice Twenty Quid Music Prize|website=Popjustice|accessdate=11 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180617165437/https://www.popjustice.com/twentyquidmusicprize/|archive-date=17 June 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
==Chart performance == In November 2012, "DNA" debuted at number three on the [[UK Singles Chart]] with first-week sales of 72,044 copies, becoming Little Mix's third consecutive top-three single in the UK.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Singles|last=Jones|first=Alan|magazine=[[Music Week]]|location=London|date=23 November 2012|page=36|issn=0265-1548}}</ref> It fell to number 12 the following week, selling 38,386 copies, and spent a total of 13 weeks on the chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Singles|last=Jones|first=Alan|magazine=Music Week|location=London|date=30 November 2012|page=36|issn=0265-1548}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/7217/little-mix/|title=Little Mix|website=[[Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=6 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190111051114/https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/7217/little-mix/|archive-date=11 January 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The song was certified gold by the [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI), and has sold over 412,000 units in the UK, according to the [[Official Charts Company]].<ref name="BPI"/><ref name="Sales">{{Cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/little-mixs-top-20-biggest-singles-on-the-official-chart__24732/|title=Little Mix's Top 20 biggest singles on the Official chart|publisher=Official Charts Company|date=15 November 2018|accessdate=9 December 2019}}</ref>
Elsewhere, "DNA" entered the [[Irish Singles Chart]] at number eight, making it the group's third consecutive top-ten single in Ireland.<ref name="irechart"/> It also reached number 10 on Hungary's Single Top 40 chart published by [[Association of Hungarian Record Companies|Magyar Hanglemezkiadók Szövetsége]] (MAHASZ).<ref name="Hungary"/> In Australia, the song peaked at number 48 and was certified gold by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) for sales of 35,000 copies.<ref name="auschart"/><ref name="AUS Cert"/> Following the album's [[Columbia Records]] release in the US in June 2013, "DNA" charted at number 14 on the US [[Bubbling Under Hot 100]].<ref name="Bubbling"/>
==Music video== ===Development and release=== [[File:Little Mix DNA video screenshot.png|thumb|250px|right|alt=Little Mix standing on a rooftop in black outfits.|The rooftop scene background was created using a [[matte painting]] and visual effects software [[Autodesk Media and Entertainment#Creative finishing|Flame]].<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/>]]
The music video for "DNA" was directed by [[Sarah Chatfield]] and produced by Tiernan Hanby.<ref name="Promonews">{{cite web|url=https://www.promonews.tv/videos/2012/10/24/little-mix-dna-sarah-chatfield/15422|title=Little Mix 'DNA' by Sarah Chatfield|last=Knight|first=David|website=Promonews|date=24 October 2012|accessdate=6 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104053324/https://www.promonews.tv/videos/2012/10/24/little-mix-dna-sarah-chatfield/15422|archive-date=4 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> It was filmed on 12 September 2012 at British production company [[Blink (company)|Blink]]'s Colonel Blimp location in London and uses [[chroma key]]ing and [[post-production]].<ref name="Details"/><ref name="Nice Biscuits">{{cite web|url=http://nicebiscuits.co.uk/project/little-mix/|title=Little Mix|website=Nicebiscuits.co.uk|accessdate=6 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190307175332/http://nicebiscuits.co.uk/project/little-mix/|archive-date=7 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The video was inspired by the comic books ''[[Sin City]]'' and ''[[Watchmen]]''; Chatfield viewed the video as "an unrelenting torrent of bold imagery and epic performances".<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/> She worked with [[visual effects]] artist Pete Young, her frequent collaborator, to develop the look she wanted for "DNA".<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/>
Little Mix's driving scenes were filmed in front of a green screen. The video's rooftop scene was developed using a [[matte painting]] by Johan Gay; the painting was separated into different layer depths then [[Compositing|composited]] into the scene using the visual effects software [[Autodesk Media and Entertainment#Creative finishing|Flame]]'s 3D tracker. [[3D modelling]] artist Greg McKneally developed computer-generated backgrounds, police cars and helicopters that were composited with reflections and light effects.<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/> Thirlwall said, "we took the theme of the song, the whole love and obsession thing, and just took it to an extreme".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/dark-dna-video/|title=Little Mix Promise To Show Off A New Side In 'Dark' Music Video For 'DNA' - Video|website=Capital|date=18 October 2012|accessdate=7 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190307173840/https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/dark-dna-video/|archive-date=7 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The group released a [[Teaser campaign|teaser trailer]] daily during a four-day countdown to the music video's Vevo premiere on 19 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a430719/little-mix-confirm-new-single-dna-music-video-premiere-watch/|title=Little Mix confirm new music video debut|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=15 October 2012|accessdate=7 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190307173807/https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a430719/little-mix-confirm-new-single-dna-music-video-premiere-watch/|archive-date=7 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> A [[making of]] video was released on 29 October 2012.<ref name="Cosmopolitan">{{cite web|url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/entertainment/a17804/watch-little-mix-behind-the-scenes-on-their-new-music-video-for-DNA/|title=Go behind the scenes with Little Mix on their video for DNA|last=Bayley|first=Leanne|website=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|date=29 October 2012|accessdate=7 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190308080736/https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/entertainment/a17804/watch-little-mix-behind-the-scenes-on-their-new-music-video-for-DNA/|archive-date=8 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
===Synopsis and reception===
The music video is in [[monochrome]] and red; it depicts Little Mix as female assassins who kidnap a man named Ryan.<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://planetradio.co.uk/cool-fm/entertainment/music/little-mix-premiere-amazing-dna-video/|title=Little Mix Premiere The Amazing 'DNA' Video!|website=[[Cool FM]]|date=20 October 2012|accessdate=9 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180707232439/https://planetradio.co.uk/cool-fm/entertainment/music/little-mix-premiere-amazing-dna-video/|archive-date=7 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> The video starts with a [[music box]] playing. During the first verse, Edwards, accompanied by a bound and gagged Ryan, travels at a high speed in a vintage car. In the next scene, Thirlwall balances on a ledge outside Ryan's bedroom window. All four group members perform a dance routine in black outfits with [[Belt (firearms)|ammunition belts]] on a rooftop for the chorus.<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a431329/little-mix-preview-dna-music-video-pictures/|title=Little Mix preview new music video|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=17 October 2012|accessdate=9 March 2019}}</ref> During the second verse, Nelson speeds in a [[convertible car]] while being chased by police.<ref name="Nice Biscuits"/> In the next segment, Pinnock is shown masterminding the group's kidnapping plan in a secret room filled with maps and clippings about Ryan that are intercut throughout the video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/dna-music-video-premiere/|title=Little Mix Get Obsessive In Their Newly Unveiled Music Video For 'DNA' - Video|website=Capital|date=19 October 2012|accessdate=9 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180707230603/http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/dna-music-video-premiere/|archive-date=7 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In the final scene, Ryan is tied to a chair in a warehouse; Little Mix stand in front of him and then walk away.<ref name="Jesy"/><ref name="Nice Biscuits"/>
''Digital Spy''{{'}}s Lewis Corner named it the eighth-best pop music video of 2012 and "one of the most diva-worthy videos from a girl group in years".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.digitalspy.ie/music/thesound/a446329/10-top-pop-music-videos-of-2012-david-guetta-gangnam-style-and-more.html|title=10 top pop music videos of 2012: David Guetta, Gangnam Style and more|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=27 December 2012|accessdate=24 May 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GrY797uu?url=http://m.digitalspy.ie/music/thesound/a446329/10-top-pop-music-videos-of-2012-david-guetta-gangnam-style-and-more.html|archivedate=24 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> Eve Barlow of ''NME'' said it "looks a little (exactly) like ''Sin City''."<ref name="NME"/>
==Live performances== [[File:2016 - Little Mix "Get Weird" (Leeds) Little Mix (25878768213).jpg|thumb|Little Mix performing "DNA" on [[The Get Weird Tour]] in 2016.|alt=Little Mix performing in black and white outfits on stage with a forest backdrop.]] Little Mix performed "DNA" live for the first time at [[BBC Radio 1#BBC Radio 1's Teen Awards|BBC Radio 1's Teen Awards]] on 7 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/tags/showbiz/772978/little-mix-perform-bbc-radio-1-teen-awards|title=Little Mix perform at BBC Radio 1 Teen Awards|last=Lucey|first=Kate|website=sugarscape.com|date=7 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211085341/http://www.sugarscape.com/tags/showbiz/772978/little-mix-perform-bbc-radio-1-teen-awards|archive-date=11 February 2013|url-status=dead|access-date=19 May 2013}}</ref> On 11 November 2012, the group performed the song on [[The X Factor (UK series 9)|the ninth UK series]] of ''The X Factor''. Backed by a troupe of male dancers, they performed in matching black, gold and blue outfits with ammunition belts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/dna-the-x-factor-performance/ |title=Little Mix 'So Nervous' As They Perform New Single 'DNA' On The X Factor |website=Capital |date=12 November 2012 |accessdate=10 March 2019}}</ref> The group performed an acoustic rendition of "DNA" for BBC Radio 1's [[Live Lounge]] on 13 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a437804/little-mix-cover-mumford-sons-i-will-wait-listen/|title=Little Mix cover Mumford & Sons|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=13 November 2012|accessdate=10 March 2019}}</ref>
Little Mix performed the track on British daytime television programme ''[[T4 (Channel 4)|T4]]'' on 18 November 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/t4/schedule|title=Schedule|website=[[Channel 4]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117095922/http://www.channel4.com/t4/schedule|archive-date=17 November 2012|access-date=18 March 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> and sang the acoustic version on British television [[panel show]] ''[[Loose Women]]'' on 23 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.little-mix.com/my/news/2012-11-23/busy-times|title=Busy times|website=Little-mix.com|date=23 November 2012|accessdate=10 March 2019}}</ref> In Ireland, they performed the song at the [[ChildLine Concert]] that aired on [[Virgin Media One|TV3]] on 1 December 2012.<ref>{{cite episode|series=[[ChildLine Concert]]|network=[[Virgin Media One|TV3]]|airdate=1 December 2012}}</ref> On 8 December 2012, the track was included in their set list for [[Capital (radio network)|Capital FM]]'s [[Jingle Bell Ball]]. Backed by a flashing heart rate monitor and sporting star-themed black-and-pink outfits, the group performed without Edwards, who was recovering from a [[tonsillectomy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/jingle-bell-ball-2012-review/|title=Little Mix Cover Nicki Minaj and Fun. During Jingle Bell Ball 2012 Performance|website=Capital|date=8 December 2012|accessdate=18 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429162237/http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/jingle-bell-ball-2012-review/|archive-date=29 April 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
During their 2013 DNA Tour, Little Mix performed the song before the [[encore]] with a live band; they were wearing monochrome outfits.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/live-reviews/a458788/little-mix-live-at-the-hammersmith-apollo-london-review/|title=Little Mix live in London - review|last=Corner|first=Lewis|website=Digital Spy|date=14 February 2013|accessdate=10 March 2019}}</ref> "DNA" was also performed during the group's set at [[BBC Radio 1's Big Weekend]] on 26 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e82wrz/acts/avfp5v|title=Little Mix - Acts - Radio 1's Big Weekend Derry~Londonderry|website=BBC|accessdate=18 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409010223/https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e82wrz/acts/avfp5v|archive-date=9 April 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> Little Mix made their US television debut with performances of "Wings" and "DNA" on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' on 7 June 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/mix-dna-girl-group-rocks-times-square-track-19348314 |title=Little Mix - DNA: Girl Group Rocks Times Square With Track Off Album |website=[[ABC News]] |date=7 June 2013 |accessdate=10 March 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703054700/http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/mix-dna-girl-group-rocks-times-square-track-19348314 |archive-date=3 July 2013|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idolator.com/7462350/little-mix-wings-good-morning-america |title=Little Mix Performs 'Wings' On 'Good Morning America': Watch |author=Gracie, Bianca |website=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] |date=7 June 2013 |accessdate=14 February 2016 }}</ref> On 8 December 2013, they performed the track again at Capital FM's Jingle Bell Ball.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/jingle-bell-ball-2013-setlist/|title=Little Mix Sing New Song 'Little Me' During Jingle Bell Ball 2013 Performance - Setlist|website=Capital|date=8 December 2013|accessdate=18 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021220230/http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/little-mix/news/jingle-bell-ball-2013-setlist/|archive-date=21 October 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> For 2014's [[The Salute Tour]], the group performed an extended version of the song; they wore black leather ensembles and were accompanied by male dancers wearing leather capes.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/review-little-mix--phones-7179325 |title=Review: Little Mix @ Phones 4u Arena |last=Evans|first=Denise |website=[[Manchester Evening News]] |date=28 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025082517/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/review-little-mix--phones-7179325 |archive-date=25 October 2015 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/music/news/a1042502/gig-review-little-mixs-salute-tour-hits-the-o2-arena-in-london/ |title=Gig Review: Little Mix's Salute tour hits the O2 Arena in London |website=sugarscape.com |date=27 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920041519/http://www.sugarscape.com/music/news/a1042502/gig-review-little-mixs-salute-tour-hits-the-o2-arena-in-london/ |archive-date=20 September 2015 |url-status=dead}}</ref> As part of Little Mix's 2016 [[The Get Weird Tour]], they performed an alternate version of "DNA" with a [[Viennese waltz]] introduction, enchanted forest backdrop and male backing dancers in [[Bondage (BDSM)|bondage]] attire and muzzles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/music/656113/Little-Mix-Get-Weird-tour-live-review-The-O2-London|title=Live review - Little Mix - The O2, London|last=Britt|first=Hannah|website=[[Daily Express]]|date=28 March 2016|accessdate=13 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911023859/http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/music/656113/Little-Mix-Get-Weird-tour-live-review-The-O2-London|archive-date=11 September 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> During their 2017 [[The Glory Days Tour]], the song was performed as part of a [[Medley (music)|medley]] with "Freak", a track from the group's fourth album ''[[Glory Days (Little Mix album)|Glory Days]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/little-mix-uk-tour-review-13749935|title=Little Mix leave Newcastle in blaze of Glory after a show full of fierceness and finesse|last=Duke|first=Simon |website=[[Evening Chronicle]] |date=11 October 2017 |accessdate=13 March 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202143806/https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/little-mix-uk-tour-review-13749935 |archive-date=2 February 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref>
==Personnel== Credits adapted from the album liner notes of ''DNA''.<ref name="Notes">{{cite AV media notes|year=2012|title=[[DNA (Little Mix album)|DNA]]|others=[[Little Mix]]|publisher=[[Syco Music]]|id=602547569646|page=8}}</ref> *TMS – production *Daniel Aslet – additional vocal engineering *Ben Collier – additional vocal engineering *Thomas Barnes – drums *Ben Kohn – guitar *Peter Kelleher – synths *Serban Ghenea – mixing *John Hanes – mix engineering *Phil Seaford – mixing assistance * [[Tom Coyne (music engineer)|Tom Coyne]] – mastering
